Award.AwardTitle: Towards an Understanding of Honest Signaling Utilizing Captive Macaques

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Animals utilize a variety of ornamentations or signals, including coloration, to attract the attention of potential mates. Such condition-dependent signals may reveal current health status and thus reflect genetic resistance to pathogens. In fact, signal expression is related to immune status in a number of species investigated to date. However, the relationships between "honest" indicators of quality and immunity have not been adequately evaluated in primates. Despite this fact, much work in primatology and human evolutionary biology is based on assumptions that these signals are indicative of immunity, and that they are related in complex ways to hormone levels. To evaluate these assumptions, a team of scholars with combined expertise will measure body condition, behavior, endocrine function, and immune function in 150 adult male and 150 adult female rhesus macaques (Macaca mulatta), each sampled during breeding and non-breeding seasons at the Tulane National Primate Research Center. It is hypothesized that sex skin coloration is an honest indicator of robust immunocompetence, and that both coloration and immunocompetence are modulated in part by the functions of various hormones.

Investigating the immunomodulatory actions of hormones allows greater understanding of the evolutionary significance of immune-endocrine interactions and provides a unique life-historical perspective on mammalian immune function. Research to clarify these interactions in nonhuman primates will provide a valuable comparative and evolutionary perspective to selection in our own species. The project also offers valuable training opportunities to graduate, undergraduate and high school students of diverse backgrounds to become members of a collaborative research community and learn sophisticated laboratory techniques and their applications. Another important applied aspect of this project includes the organization of a workshop on biomarkers in evolutionary anthropology. Future project development will include additional hormone and genetic analyses in remaining samples collected and stored from the current project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How do animals choose who to mate with? One idea is that they evaluate traits in potential mates that might indicate something about quality, a quality that can be passed down to offspring. Animals of course do not contemplate why they find something attractive, they just do. But we can evaluate the biological significance of these traits that are most commonly found to be attractive in a particular species. There must be variation in these traits, otherwise all animals would express them equally. And, by extension, these traits must only be found in animals of higher “quality” (so cannot be misrepresented by other animals). This is thought to be the basis of secondary sexual characteristics in many species, including pigmentation in several species of primates. To investigate this issue more thoroughly, a collaboration of almost twenty scholars, technicians, and students set out measuring captive rhesus macaques (Macaca mulatta) so as to identify relationships among measures of body condition (including red coloration around the eyes and genitals that increases significantly during the breeding season, and which has been demonstrated attractive to potential mates in this species), behavior (dominance status), endocrine function (the hormones testosterone, dehydroepiandrosterone, dehydroepiandrosterone-sulphate, cortisol, estradiol, and leptin), and immune function (including the ability of some white blood cells to divide and produce anti-microbial substances, as well as new methods not previously utilized in nonhuman primates). Our objectives were to: 1) produce a detailed analysis of predictive relationships among immune function, endocrine function, and external signals of health; 2) examine the underlying endocrine regulators of immunity; and 3) contribute to the development and use of methodologies for measuring immunity and body condition in nonhuman primates. The specific aims of this project were to answer the following research questions: how is seasonal variation in sex skin coloration indicative of immune function and endocrine function; how are hormones related to immunity in these animals; and how do immunity, hormones, and body condition (and relationships among these variables) change across the breeding and nonbreeding seasons?

 We have amassed a large database containing results of all above-mentioned immune and endocrine measures from almost 300 rhesus macaque samples. New methods have been developed for evaluating immune function in this and other nonhuman primate species. A physical specimen collection now includes serum, plasma, whole blood, extracted DNA and RNA, and purified, cryopreserved white blood cells from all animals. Immune assay protocols are already available to researchers online, and future investigators may apply for access to stored samples. Furthermore, a database has been created, with all results and analyses to be shared publically, and a workshop on biomarkers for anthropology graduate students is currently being planned. Publications in open-access format will be submitted once all data analyses are completed. 

Our study constitutes the first effort to analyze the interrelationships among hormones, immunity, and external signals in nonhuman primates, using sophisticated methods for measuring skin coloration and immunity. Research to clarify sexual signaling and immune-endocrine interactions in nonhuman primates will also provide a valuable comparative and evolutionary perspective to sexual selection work in our own species.
